revision.text:
This article describes the rules of [[judo]]. The main sections of the article describe the rules that apply to any situation in which judo is practiced, and those rules which apply only in judo competitions. Separate sections describe the history of the rules of judo, provide links to other sources of information on '''judo rules''', and list the references for this article.
== In practice and competition ==
=== Safety ===
* Intentionally injuring an opponent is not permitted. * Punching, kicking, and other strikes are not allowed. * Touching the opponent's face is not allowed. * Attacking joints other than the elbow is not allowed.<ref>IJF Rules, Section 27.b.25</ref> * ''Head dives'' are not permitted.<ref>IJF Rules, Section 27.b.32</ref> * The technique known as [[kawazu gake]] is not permitted.<ref>IJF Rules, Section 27.b.24</ref> * The technique known as [[Kani Basami|kani basami]] is not permitted. * Wearing any hard or metallic object during competition is not permitted. The penalty for violating this rule is ''hansoku make'' (see '''Penalties''', below).<ref>IJF Rules, Section 27.b.34)</ref> This includes wedding rings, earrings, hard-plastic protective gear, hair-ties with metal parts, wristwatches, and even press-studs on underpants.
=== Etiquette ===
* Contestants must bow before stepping onto the mat. * Contestants must bow to each other before and after practice or competition. * Inappropriate behaviour, such as foul language and bodily gestures, is not tolerated.
==In competition only==
* Stalling is not permitted. * Using a defensive posture is not permitted. * It is required to bow to the competition area. * False attacks are not permitted. They are considered attempts to circumvent the prohibition against noncombativity. * Disregarding the orders of the judge is prohibited.
=== Scoring === <!-- need to elaborate on the following items --> The scoring rules in use starting in 2017 are as follows: * Awarding of [[ippon]] (一本) 'One full point'. Award of ippon decides the winner and ends the match. Ippon is awarded for a successful throw performed with control and power, or for a pin lasting 20 seconds. Submission by strangulation or application of an arm lock at the elbow joint also results in ippon. * Awarding of [[waza-ari]] (技あり). 'One half point'. Awarded for a successful throw lacking one of the above elements, or for a pin lasting 10 seconds. The following rules are no longer in use: * Until 2017, when two waza-ari are awarded in the same match, they were considered to be same as ippon and the match ended (the judge exclaimed 'Waza-ari, awasete ippon', or "Waza-ari to make ippon") * Awarding of [[Yuko (judo)#Competition scoring|yuko]] (有効). One score of waza-ari was considered greater than any number of yuko scores. From 2008 to 2016, yuko was the smallest score that can be awarded. Yuko was removed from IJF competition in 2017. * Awarding of koka <!-- The article [[Koka]] is about the Koka Era in Japanese history 1844-1848 and doesn't mention Judo. --> (効果). Was introduced in 1975 and removed from IJF competition at the end of 2008. Any number of koka scores does not add up to a yuko score.<ref>http://judoinfo.com/pdf/Contest%20Rules-08.pdf</ref><ref>http://judoinfo.com/rules2.htm</ref>
=== Penalties === Two types of penalties may be awarded. A ''shido'' (指導; literally "guidance" or "instruction") is awarded for minor rule infringements. A shido can also be awarded for a prolonged period of non-aggression. Recent rule changes allow for the first shidos to result in only warnings. If there is a tie, then and only then, will the number of shidos (if less than three) be used to determine the winner. After three shidos are given, the victory is given to the opponent. This is an indirect hansoku-make, and does not result in expulsion from the tournament. The penalty of ''hansoku make'' (反則負け; literally "foul-play loss") is awarded for major rule infringements, or for accumulating three ''shidos''. If ''hansoku make'' is awarded for a major rule infringement, it results not just in loss of the match, but in expulsion from the tournament.<ref>See Angus (2006) pp. 15-18 for a detailed explanation of judo penalties.</ref> Note: Prior to 2017, the 4th shido was hansoku make.
=== Competition area === The competition area must be padded with [[tatami]]. The minimum allowable size is 14 x 14 meters. The match takes place in an 8 x 8 meter to 10 x 10 meter zone within this larger area. The surrounding space acts as a safety zone. When two competition areas are side by side, there must be at least a 3-meter safety zone between them.<ref>IJF Referee Rules, Section 1, ''Competition Area''</ref>
=== Grips === Rules related to grips are primarily motivated by the desire to avoid stalling, to avoid providing undue advantage, or to reduce the chance of injury.
* Deliberately avoiding gripping is not permitted.<ref>IJF rules, Section 27.a.1</ref> * In a standing position, it is not permitted to take any grip other than a "normal" grip for more than three to five seconds without attacking. A "normal" grip is one where the right hand grips some part of the left/right hand side of the opponent's jacket (and the left hand grips some part of the right hand side of the opponent's jacket, vice versa.) A non-normal grip may involve grabbing the belt, or the trousers, or the wrong side of the jacket.<ref>IJF rules, Section 27.a.10</ref> (A non-"standard" grip is one that does not involve the traditional sleeve/collar grip. There are no time-limits related to non-"standard" grips as long as they are not non-"normal".) * A "pistol grip" on the opponent's sleeve is permitted if immediate attack is launched.<ref>IJF rules 2018-2020, slide [http://99e89a50309ad79ff91d-082b8fd5551e97bc65e327988b444396.r14.cf3.rackcdn.com/up/2018/03/Explanatory_guide_of_the_judo_-1520605350.pdf 44]</ref> * It is not permitted to insert the fingers inside the opponent's sleeve opening or trousers opening at any time. You are permitted to insert your fingers inside your own gi openings. * Biting the opponent's gi is prohibited, as it grants another gripping point. *Since 2010, it is not permitted to grab the legs or trousers, initially, during tachi-waza (standing techniques). As of 9 February 2013 it is no longer permissible to touch the legs of the opponent whatsoever during tachi-waza.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.intjudo.eu/editor_up/up/IJF%20REF%20RULES_Final%20print%20vers_2011-12_ENG_Final_amended.pdf|title = International Judo Federation|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Furthermore, it is no longer permissible to break an opponent's grip with two hands.
=== Age ===
Judo competitions typically have some safety-related rules related to age: chokes are prohibited under a certain age (typically 13<ref>[http://www.judoinfo.com/chokes.htm] Principles of Judo Choking Techniques</ref>), and arm bars are prohibited under a certain age (typically 16).
The duration of matches is also dependent on the age of the competitors. Match length is typically three minutes for children, five minutes for teenagers and young adults, and three minutes for 'masters' (adults thirty years of age or older).
=== Gi ===
Rules related to the [[Judogi|gi]] are primarily related either to safety or to preventing contestants from wearing gis that prevent their opponent from being able to get a grip on them.
* The sleeves of the jacket are not allowed to be too short: cut the leg they must extend down to no more than 5 cm above the wrists with the arms extended in front of the body.<ref>IJF Rules, Section 3.d</ref> * The legs of the trousers are not allowed to be too short: they must extend down to no more than 5 cm above the ankle.<ref>IJF Rules, Section 3.e</ref> * Excessive advertising on the gi must be avoided, and may result in a forced loss if an appropriate gi can't be found.
=== Medical treatment, illness, and injury ===
The official [[International Judo Federation]] (IJF) rules related to the provision of medical treatment and to the proper handling of situations involving illness or injury are relatively long and involved, since the exact nature and cause of an injury may themselves affect the awarding of the match, and since receiving some types of medical treatment, but not others, automatically ends the match. The latter fact makes it necessary for medical attendants at judo matches to have some understanding of this rather complex aspect of the rules of judo. The medical team is not allowed to enter the fighting area without permission from the mat judge, and if a contestant receives medical treatment he automatically forfeits the match. Nosebleeds, for example cannot be treated by the medical team, the contestant must fix it himself with materials provided by the medical team, proper procedure is stuffing cotton balls up the nostrils, while applying tape around the head. If a contestant is rendered unconscious without a choking technique, and is unable to wake up, the medical team has to take immediate action and they can't wait for the contestant's consent, he forfeits the match automatically. A contestant can ignore any injuries he has, and keep fighting. This requires that it is not of any discomfort to the opponent, e.g. bleeding over an opponent can cause penalties. If the bleeding is tried to be stopped three times, with no effect, the match is forfeited.
== History ==
* Effect of Russian gripping strategies on the grip-related rules.<ref>see Angus, p. 29</ref> * The technique known as [[Kani Basami|kani basami]] was banned in 1980 after [[Yasuhiro Yamashita]] suffered a broken leg while being thrown with it. * Motivation for banning of head-dives.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Sources ==
* The IJF rules are the official published reference for the rules of judo competition (see External links, below). However, rules can be changed by committee decision between official releases of the published rules, and these are not published on the IJF site. * '''Mastering judo''' by Masao Takahashi et al., explains a number of aspects of the rules. General rules of competition, etiquette, and the penalty system are covered in Chapter 2. {{ISBN|0-7360-5099-X}}. * The first chapter of '''Competitive judo: winning training and techniques''', by [[Ron Angus]], is devoted to explaining a number of aspects of the rules. {{ISBN|0-7360-5744-7}}.
== External links == * [http://www.intjudo.eu/?Menu=Static_Page&Action=List&m_static_id=42&lang_id=2&mid=7&main=12 IJF (International Judo Federation) Rules and Referee Guide]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Judo Rules}} [[Category:Judo|Rules]] [[Category:Sports rules and regulations by sport]]

1992–''present'' |mens_ranking = 12 |womens_ranking = 16 |website = http://www.lhf.lv/ |logo_size=100px}} The '''Latvian Ice Hockey Federation''' ({{lang-lv|Latvijas Hokeja federācija}}), commonly abbreviated as '''LHF''' is the [[Sport governing body|governing body]] that oversees [[ice hockey]] in [[Latvia]], including the [[Latvian Hockey Higher League]], the [[Latvia women's national ice hockey team]] and the [[Latvia men's national ice hockey team]].{{cite web|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1042425/former-prime-minister-appointed-as-president-of-latvian-ice-hockey-federation|title=Former Prime Minister appointed as President of Latvian Ice Hockey Federation|publisher=|accessdate=21 December 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lsm.lv/en/article/sports/culture/gas-utility-boss-becomes-ice-hockey-federation-president.a204385/|title=Gas utility boss becomes Ice Hockey Federation president|publisher=|accessdate=21 December 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://thehockeywriters.com/history-latvian-hockey/|title=The History of Latvian Hockey|date=18 November 2013|publisher=|accessdate=21 December 2016}} It was founded in 1931. == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.lhf.lv/}} *[http://www.iihf.com/iihf-home/countries/latvia.html Latvia] at IIHF.com {{Sports governing bodies in Latvia}} {{IIHF member associations}} [[Category:Ice hockey in Latvia]] [[Category:International Ice Hockey Federation members]] [[Category:Ice hockey governing bodies in Europe]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Latvia]] {{icehockey-stub}} {{Latvia-sport-stub}}

revision.text:
{{redirect|Lay-up|ships that are "in lay-up" or "laid up"|In ordinary|and|Reserve fleet}} {{unreferenced|date=February 2011}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | width = <!-- Digits only; no "px" suffix, please --> | image1 = 20130103 Trey Burke Layup (2).JPG | width1 = 125 | image2 = 20130103 Trey Burke Layup (3).JPG | width2 = 125 | image3 = 20130103 Trey Burke Layup (4).JPG | width3 = 125 | footer = A layup by [[Trey Burke]] for the [[Michigan Wolverines]] in the [[2012–13 Big Ten Conference men's basketball season]] opener on January 3 against [[2012–13 Northwestern Wildcats men's basketball team|Northwestern]] }} A '''layup''' in [[basketball]] is a two-point shot attempt made by leaping from below, laying the ball up near the basket, and using one hand to bounce it off the backboard and into the basket. The motion and one-handed reach distinguish it from a [[Jump shot (basketball)|jump shot]]. The layup is considered the most basic shot in basketball. When doing a layup, the player lifts the outside foot, or the foot away from the basket. It is a foul if, during your layup, you hold the other person's hand or push it away to avoid him or her from defending. On the other hand, it is considered a foul if the defender jumps in front of you in the middle of nowhere and you both crash, in this case the defender causes a foul. A layup is very handy and to defend it, you just basically need to stand in front of the opponent with your arms stretched out.
An undefended layup is usually a high percentage shot. The main obstacle is getting near the rim and avoiding [[block (basketball)|blocks]] by taller defenders who usually stand near the basket. Common layup strategies are to create spaces, release the ball from a different spot, or use alternate hands. A player able to reach over the rim might choose to perform a more spectacular and higher percentage [[slam dunk]] (dropping or throwing the ball from above the rim) instead.
==Versions== [[File:20140402 MCDAAG Emmanuel Mudiay reverse layup.JPG|thumb|[[Emmanuel Mudiay]] does a reverse layup in the [[2014 McDonald's All-American Boys Game]]]] As the game has evolved through the years, so has the layup. Several different versions of the layup are around today. Layups can be broadly categorized into two types: the underarm and the overarm. The underarm layup involves using most of the wrist and the fingers to 'lay' the ball into the net or off the board. This layup is more commonly known as the [[finger roll]]. [[George Gervin]] was one of the early practitioners of a showy finger roll layup. Notable past NBA players who rely heavily on the underarm finger roll are [[Mike Bibby]] and [[Allen Iverson]].
Finger rolls today have many forms, including the "Around the World" which involves a complete circle around the player before the layup and a variety of faking in the approach to the rim. A classic example is a play by [[Jason Williams (basketball, born 1975)|Jason Williams]] during his time with [[Sacramento Kings|Sacramento]], in which Williams brought the ball behind his back with his right hand, in a fake of a back pass, and then brought it front again with the same hand for the finish (reminiscent of [[Bob Cousy]], who pioneered the move).
The other layup is the overhand shot, similar to a jump shot but from a considerably close range. Overhand layups nearly always involve the action of the backboard. Players like [[Scottie Pippen]] and [[Karl Malone]] have used this move to great effect.
The Reverse Layup is a more stylish method of making the ball from close. Generally you fake the defender into defending a regular layup on the near side and then jump to the far side of the basket before shooting.
It is common for players to create room for a layup by making use of the allotted two steps before the layup attempt. Variations and improvisations exist, yet the most common form is the 'Euro-Step'. So called as it was introduced to the NBA by European players, it has been adopted mainly by guards and forwardsas it relies heavily on agility and footwork to avoid larger defenders, although bigger players such as Joel Embiid have been seen making use of the move. The Euro-Step itself involves picking up one's dribble while dribbling, taking one step in one direction, then quickly taking a step in the other direction to avoid the defender to create room for a layup attempt. To make use of the move efficiently, it is best to dribble in aggressively then take two broad steps in different directions while simultaneously bringing the ball over one's head in the direction one is stepping for maximum evasion and protection while potentially drawing a foul.
Michael Carter-Williams has not made a layup in an actual NBA Game. He is the only player that has attempted over 100 and made none.
==Gallery== <gallery> Safata Van Rossom.webm|[[Sam Van Rossom]] layups in a [[Valencia Basket]] match. </gallery>
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090221173520/http://www.youth-basketball-tips.com/how-to-shoot-a-basketball.html Information on Layup and Variants] *{{Cite web|title=How to do a Reverse Layup in Basketball|website=Wikihow.com|accessdate=11 Feb 2014|url=http://www.wikihow.com/Shoot-a-Reverse-Layup-in-Basketball}} *[http://www.ecbahoops.com/basketball-jump-shots/basketball-shooting-types/ Layups and Dunks]
{{basketball}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Lou Brock Sports Complex | nickname = | image = | location = [[St. Charles, Missouri]] | coordinates = {{Coord|38.7872|-90.5067}}| broke_ground = | opened = 2005 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Lindenwood University]] | operator = Lindenwood University | surface = Enviroturf (synthetic grass)| construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Lindenwood Lions]] ([[National Collegiate Athletics Association|NCAA]]) | seating_capacity = 700 (baseball)
300 (softball)| dimensions = Left Field - 322 ft
Center Field - 385 ft
Right Field - 322 ft }} '''Lou Brock Sports Complex''' is college athletic complex located in [[St. Charles, Missouri|St. Charles]] [[Missouri]] that includes a [[baseball]] [[stadium]] and softball stadium.{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Cedric|publisher=The Current|url=http://thecurrent-online.com/sports/umsl-baseball-field-to-host-some-glvc-tournament-games/|title=UMSL Baseball Field to host some GLVC Tournament Games|date=March 8, 2010|accessdate=June 20, 2010}} It is the home field of the [[Lindenwood University]] [[Lindenwood Lions|Lions]] baseball and softball teams.{{cite news|last=DeMoulin|first=Nicole|publisher=[[The Legacy (Lindenwood University)|The Legacy]]|url=http://media.www.lulegacy.com/media/storage/paper1262/news/2008/04/24/Sports/Overcrowded.Athletic.Facilities.Puts.Practice.Time.At.Premium-3345894.shtml|title=Overcrowded athletic facilities puts practice time at premium|date=April 24, 2008|accessdate=June 20, 2010}} It is named after former [[St. Louis Cardinals]] player and member of the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|National Baseball Hall of Fame]], [[Lou Brock]].{{cite news|last=Neunuebel|first=Greg|publisher=[[St. Louis Post Dispatch]]|url=http://www.stltoday.com/suburban-journals/stcharles/news/article_ee3d882a-2745-5dbc-8c16-4e89cb3c2786.html|title=Brock statue will symbolize life's 'breakthrough' moments|date=April 12, 2011|accessdate=April 17, 2011}} The Sports Complex was built in 2005 under the university's expansion plans.{{cite news|first=Gil|last=Stuenkel|work=[[St. Louis Business Journal]]|url=http://stlouis.bizjournals.com/stlouis/stories/2008/11/24/focus3.html|title=Curtain rises on new theater at Lindenwood|date=November 23, 2008|accessdate=June 18, 2010}} It has hosted [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] regional tournaments along with the 2009 NAIA Baseball National Championship Opening Round.{{cite news|last=Woodard|first=Micah|publisher=[[The Legacy (Lindenwood University)|The Legacy]]|url=http://media.www.lulegacy.com/media/storage/paper1262/news/2008/05/08/Sports/Lions.Overcome.Adversity.To.Reach-3367753.shtml|title=Lions overcome adversity to reach|date=May 8, 2008|accessdate=June 20, 2010}}{{cite web|work=[[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]]|url=http://naia.cstv.com/genrel/083106aaa.html|title=Lindenwood University (Mo.) Loses its No. 1 Sports Fan|date=August 31, 2006|accessdate=June 20, 2010}} The baseball stadium at Lou Brock features permanent, bleacher seating for 700 spectators. These seats wrap around the foul territory behind home plate. The adjacent softball field features seating for around 300 spectators behind homeplate.{{cite web|work=Lindenwood University|title=2010-11 Student Handbook| url=http://www.lindenwood.edu/studentDevelopment/docs/HB/StudentHB.pdf|year=2010|accessdate=July 13, 2010}} a Clubhouse is located down the right field line of the baseball field and contains space for a variety of functions for the team and includes the team's locker room. Both fields include a pressbox, which enables radio broadcasts and is used by media members and game day staff. A concession stand is located in a concourse between the baseball field and softball field.{{cite web|work=Lindenwood University|url=http://www.lindenwoodlions.com/sports/2009/7/13/facilities.aspx?tab=facilities#Brock|title=Facilities: Lou Brock Sports Complex|accessdate=June 20, 2010}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.lindenwoodlions.com/sports/2009/7/13/facilities.aspx?tab=facilities#Brock Lou Brock Sport Complex] {{Lindenwood University}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Missouri]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College softball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2005]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in St. Charles County, Missouri]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Missouri]] {{Missouri-baseball-venue-stub}}

[[Paul Sorvino]]
[[Chris Noth]]

[[Angela Bassett]] | music = [[John Powell (composer)|John Powell]] | cinematography = [[Shane Hurlbut]] | editing = [[Bill Pankow]] | studio = [[Touchstone Pictures]]

[[Spyglass Entertainment]]
[[The Kennedy/Marshall Company]] | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Buena Vista Pictures]] | released = September 17, 2004 | runtime = 104 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $30 million | gross = $21,839,377 }} '''''Mr. 3000''''' is a 2004 American [[List of sports films|sports]] [[comedy film]] starring [[Bernie Mac]] and [[Angela Bassett]]. The film's plot surrounds a retired [[Major League Baseball]] player who makes a comeback at age 47 in order to attain [[3,000 hit club|3,000 hits]]. ==Plot== Stan Ross is the franchise player of the [[Milwaukee Brewers]] [[baseball]] team. After recording his 3,000th [[hit (baseball)|hit]], the selfish, narcissistic Ross immediately retires, leaving the team without one of its star players in the middle of the [[1995 Milwaukee Brewers season|1995]] [[Playoffs#Major League Baseball|playoff]] race, showing every bit of disregard for his teammates' feelings. During the next nine years, Ross uses his nickname as a business tool, owning several profitable properties under the name "Mr. 3000" that make him increasingly wealthy. In 2004, the Brewers [[List of Major League Baseball retired numbers|retire Ross' number]] so they can get rid of Ross for good, and also draw a large crowd. Although many fans come to the ceremony, other players, including teammates and fellow stars [[Robin Yount]], [[Cecil Cooper]], and [[Paul Molitor]], stay away. Only his best friend Anthony (Boca) Carter and a [[middle relief pitcher]] from his early days in the majors named Bill (Big Horse) Berelli attend, and the ex-pitcher chastises Ross for his arrogant attitude. Ross learns that, due to a [[clerical error]], he retired with 2,997 hits instead of 3,000. The error also partially contributes to Ross not being voted into the [[Baseball Hall of Fame]]Voters have elected all eligible ([[Pete Rose]] is ineligible) players with 3,000 or more hits to the Hall of Fame, except for controversial player [[Rafael Palmeiro]]. and makes his "Mr. 3000" marketing gimmick inaccurate. Ross seeks to return to the game at the age of 47 to get three more hits, secure his place in the record books, and keep his local post-career marketing gimmick intact. A top Brewers executive, citing the large attendance at Ross' number retirement ceremony and the fact that the Brewers are out of playoff contention, agrees to bring Ross back during the [[Major League Baseball rosters|September roster expansion]]. The team's younger players only know of Ross as a self-centered player, and team superstar Rex "T-Rex" Pennebaker, who is pompous and arrogant like Ross, sees him as unneeded and too old to play. Manager Gus Panas refuses to speak to Ross because of his abrupt retirement, and the [[sportswriting|sportswriters]] continually criticize him. Despite his predictions to the contrary Ross struggles to regain his baseball form. He goes hitless in his first 27 at-bats. His comeback is reported by television sportscaster Maureen "Mo" Simmons, who resumes a former romantic relationship with Ross. He gets two hits, including a home run, to increase his career total to 2,999. Ross becomes a mentor to the younger players and urges Pennebaker to learn from his own mistakes as a baseball star and to be a team player, so that Pennebaker will not end up like him – all alone. This inspires the Brewers to a late-season comeback and a respectable finish. Ross attempts to become serious with Simmons and make her a permanent part of his life, but she is reluctant to believe he is a changed man, particularly after he skips a team practice to go on national television with [[Jay Leno]] and begin boasting again. In his last at-bat of the season, with a chance to be a hero, Ross has a vision of his earlier years, when he was considered always dependable for the team. It inspires him to sacrifice his last chance with a [[Bunt (baseball)|bunt]] instead so the team can win a game and finish third in [[National League Central|its division]]. Although Ross never reaches the "3,000" milestone, his newfound generosity and attitude gets him inducted into the Hall of Fame. He renames his businesses "Mr. 2,999." ==Cast== * [[Bernie Mac]] – Stan Ross * [[Angela Bassett]] – Maureen Simmons * [[Michael Rispoli]] – Anthony (Boca) Carter * [[Brian J. White]] – Rex (T-Rex) Pennebaker * [[Ian Anthony Dale]] – Fukuda * [[Evan Jones (actor)|Evan Jones]] – Fryman * [[Amaury Nolasco]] – Jorge Minadeo * [[Dondre Whitfield]] – Skillet * [[Paul Sorvino]] – Gus Panas * [[Earl Billings]] – Lenny Koron * [[Chris Noth]] – Schiembri ==Production== Portions of the film were filmed at [[Marquette University High School]], as well as [[Miller Park (Milwaukee)|Miller Park]], in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]],{{cite web|url=https://marquettewire.org/3885606/tribune/marquee/mke-locations-scenery-utilized-in-well-known-films/|title=MKE locations, scenery utilized in well-known films|first=Stephanie|last=Harte|website=Marquettewire.org|accessdate=August 17, 2017}} and at [[Zephyr Field]] in [[New Orleans, Louisiana]].{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} ==Reception== The film received mixed reviews, earning a score of 54% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] which observed "Bernie Mac demonstrates he can play the game even if the movie's a few innings short of a complete game."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/mr_3000/ |title=Mr. 3000 |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |date= |accessdate=July 15, 2013}} The film took over $8 million at the box office on its [[opening weekend]]. In all it took $21,811,169 in the US and Canada, and a further $28,190 when it was released in Spain, for a global total of $21,839,377.{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=mr3000.htm |title=Mr. 3000 (2004) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date=December 23, 2004 |accessdate=July 15, 2013}} ==Soundtrack== # "[[Shining Star (Earth, Wind & Fire song)|Shining Star]]" - [[Earth, Wind & Fire]] # "[[Jungle Boogie]]" - [[Kool & the Gang]] # "[[Ain't No Stoppin' Us Now]]" - [[McFadden & Whitehead]] # "[[Let's Get It On (song)|Let's Get It On]]" - [[Marvin Gaye]] # "[[Why Can't We Be Friends? (song)|Why Can't We Be Friends]]" - [[War (band)|War & Peace]] # "[[Respect Yourself]]" - [[The Staple Singers]] # "[[Let's Groove]]" - [[Earth, Wind & Fire]] # "[[I Gotcha (Joe Tex song)|I Gotcha]]" - [[Joe Tex]] # "Getting Nasty" - [[Ike & Tina Turner]] # "[[Super Bad (song)|Super Bad]]" - [[James Brown]] # "[[Turn Back the Hands of Time]]" - [[Tyrone Davis]] # "[[The Best Is Yet to Come]]" - [[Steve Lawrence]] # "[[If You Don't Know Me by Now]]" - [[Calvin Richardson]] # "[[It Takes Two (Rob Base & DJ E-Z Rock song)|It Takes Two]]" - [[Rob Base]] {{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/mr-3000-mw0000397847 |title=Mr. 3000 – Original Soundtrack – Songs, Reviews, Credits |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=August 17, 2017 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0339412|Mr. 3000}} * {{Amg title|288103|Mr. 3000}} * {{mojo title|mr3000|Mr. 3000}} {{Charles Stone III}} {{Milwaukee Brewers}} [[Category:Milwaukee Brewers]] [[Category:2004 films]] [[Category:2000s comedy films]] [[Category:2000s sports films]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:American sports comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films set in Milwaukee]] [[Category:Spyglass Entertainment films]] [[Category:The Kennedy/Marshall Company films]] [[Category:Touchstone Pictures films]] [[Category:Dimension Films films]] [[Category:Films directed by Charles Stone III]] [[Category:Films produced by Roger Birnbaum]] [[Category:Films scored by John Powell]]

{{Infobox sports club | clubname = Muhafızgücü SK | image = Muhafızgücü_logo.jpg | fullname = Muhafızgücü Spor Kulübü | nickname = | founded = 1920 as ''Muhafız Alayı'' | dissolved = 1981 | colors = {{colorbox|#FF0000}} {{colorbox|#FFFFFF}} Red and white }} '''Muhafızgücü SK''' were a [[Turkey|Turkish]] [[sports club]] based in [[Ankara]], Turkey. The club was founded in Ankara after order by [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]] on July 18, 1920.<ref>[http://www.atamizindeyiz.net/ata/ataturk_ve_spor.html Sports club founded by Atatürk's order] {{tr icon}}</ref> The club was founded under the name ''Muhafız Alayı'' by Mülazım İsmail Hakkı Bey as chairman. On 1 June 1923, the club's name was changed to Muhafızgücü.<ref>{{cite book| last = Bozok | first = Salih | contributor = | year = 1985 | title = Hep Atatürk'ün Yanında | publisher = Çağdaş Yayınları | pages = 84}}</ref> Muhafızgücü were active in [[association football|football]], [[basketball]], [[sport of athletics|athletics]], [[equestrianism]], [[cycling]], [[polo]], and [[volleyball]]. They achieved their greatest success in football, when they became [[Turkish Football Championship|Turkish champions]] in [[1927 Turkish Football Championship|1927]] and in basketball, as they won the [[Basketbol Süper Ligi|Turkish League]] in the 1973–74 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://basketdergisi.com/baskentten-cikan-sampiyonu-hatirlayan-var-mi-togan-karatas.html|title=Başkentten çıkan şampiyonu hatırlayan var mı?|website=basketdergisi.com|accessdate=30 April 2018|language=Turkish}}</ref>
Since Muhafızgücü were a military club their colors were red and white, the colors of the [[Flag of Turkey|Turkish flag]]. The club was dissolved in 1981.
==Honours== <ref name="TamSaha">{{cite web|url=http://www.tff.org/resources/tamsaha/135/files/assets/common/downloads/TamSaha.pdf|title=TamSaha dergisi|issue=135|page=90|language=Turkish|date=February 2016|accessdate=27 December 2017|publisher=[[Turkish Football Federation]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170817035003/http://www.tff.org/resources/tamsaha/135/files/assets/common/downloads/TamSaha.pdf|archivedate=27 December 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablest/turkchamp.html|title=Turkey - List of Champions|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]]|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvf.org.tr/sezon-sampiyonlari/|title=ERKEKLER LİG ŞAMPİYONLUKLARI|publisher=[[Turkish Volleyball Federation]]|accessdate=30 April 2018|language=Turkish}}</ref> In Turkey, Muhafızgücü are one of three sports clubs who have won national championships in football, basketball, and volleyball.

* '''[[Ankara Football League]]''' : '''Winners (5):''' 1924–25, 1925–26, 1926–27, 1927–28, 1928–29 : ''Runners-up (7):'' 1923–24, 1930–31, 1932–33, 1934–35, 1937–38, 1939–40, 1945–46

{{Infobox venue | name = Olympic Oval | nickname = | fullname = | image = Olympic Oval.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Olympic Oval in 2006 | location = 2500 University Drive NW
[[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], Canada | coordinates ={{Coord|51.077|N|114.136|W|type:landmark_region:CA|display=it|name=Olympic Oval}} | broke_ground = 1985 | opened = September 1987 | owner = [[University of Calgary]] | operator = University of Calgary,
Faculty of Kinesiology | cost = [[Canadian dollar|$]]38.9 Million | architect = Graham – McCourt | seating_capacity = 2,000 - permanent seating
{{nowrap|4,000 w/ temporary seating{{citation |title=Calgary Olympic Oval Self Guided Tour: Panel 4 – The Building |publisher=Ice Speed Skating Ovals and Clubs in Canada}}}} | tenants = National Speed Skating Team, National Speed Skating Development Team, Oval Program, University of Calgary Dinos Hockey |website = [http://www.oval.ucalgary.ca/ oval.ucalgary.ca] }} The '''Olympic Oval''' in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], Canada, is a covered [[speed skating]] oval; it was built for the [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics|1988 Winter Olympics]] and opened {{Years or months ago|1987}} in 1987.[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1988/orw1988pt1.pdf 1988 Winter Olympics official report.] Part 1. pp. 144-51. Located on the [[University of Calgary]] campus, it is the official designated training center for Speed Skate Canada and the Canadian National Speed Skating team. In 2012, it commemorated its 25th year of public service with a number of exciting activities and celebrations. ==History== The Olympic Oval was designed as the first covered speed skating oval in [[North America]], and was the first at a [[Speed skating at the Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]]. The indoor facility offered the ability to control climate conditions to produce the highest quality ice. Construction of The Oval began in 1985, nearly four years after Calgary had been designated host of the [[1988 Winter Olympics|XV Olympic Winter Games]]. Like the [[Olympic Saddledome]], most of the Oval's structure was built using precast, prestressed concrete. Twenty eight beams were laid along the outside of the perimeter of the building to support 84 additional beams used to construct a lattice frame for the arched roof. The interior scaffolding used to hoist these 84 beams had to be lowered a centimetre at a time in a predetermined sequence in order to distribute the load of the roof equally to each of the 28 exterior support beams. Construction was completed by the end of the summer of 1987, officially opening in September 1987, five months before the Olympics. [[Image:Olympic Oval Aerial 1.jpg|left|thumb|Olympic Oval in 2007]] It was during the [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics|speed skating events]] of the Olympic Winter Games in 1988 that The Oval became known as ''"the fastest ice on Earth,"'' as world records were set in seven events ([[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Men's 500 metres|Men's 500 m]], [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|1500 m]], [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Men's 10,000 metres|10,000 m]], and [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Women's 500 metres|Women's 500 m]], [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Women's 1000 metres|1000 m]], [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Women's 3000 metres|3000 m]], [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Women's 5000 metres|5000 m]]), and Olympic records were set in the other three events ([[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|Men's 1500 m]], [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Men's 5000 metres|5000 m]], and [[Speed skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics – Women's 1500 metres|Women's 1500 m]]). The combination of the climate-controlled facility and the effects of high altitude have been credited for the fast ice surface. Seven world and three Olympic records were broken during the Games, resulting in the facility earning praise as "the fastest ice on Earth".{{cite news |title=Building on the Olympic Legacy |newspaper=Calgary Herald |date=February 9, 2013}}{{rp|A15–A16}} Throughout the following 14 years the vast majority of speed skating world records were set at The Oval. By 2013, at celebrations for the 25th anniversary of the 1988 Winter Games, the former CEO of the Winter Games said that the Olympic Oval had produced over "150 world record skating times".{{cite news |newspaper=Calgary Herald |url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/sports/Calgary+celebrates+legacy+1988+Winter+Olympics/7961936/story.html |title=Calgary celebrates legacy of 1988 Winter Olympics |first=Eva |last=Ferguson |date=February 18, 2013 |access-date=November 27, 2018}} ==Training facility== [[Image:Olympic Oval Panorama1.jpg|thumb|750px|left|A panorama taken from the northeast corner of the facility.]]Along with the 400 m long-track speed skating oval, the Olympic Oval also includes two international-sized ice rinks for short-track speed skating and ice hockey, a 450 m running track surrounding the main oval, and an eight-lane 110 m sprint track for year-round athletics training. By 2013, hundred of Canadian athletes were training in the Oval year round. [[Saskatoon]]-native [[Catriona Le May Doan]], who won the gold medal in speedskating at the [[1998 Winter Olympics]] and in the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] began training at the Oval soon after its construction. The Oval continues to be regarded as a premier speed skating venue, and a preferred training facility for speed skating teams across the globe. ==Other activities== When not hosting hockey games and speed skating competitions, The Oval is open to public skating, family day events, and the Calgary Science Fair. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official|http://www.oval.ucalgary.ca/}} * [http://www.la84foundation.org/OlympicInformationCenter/OlympicReview/1988/ore243/ORE243k.pdf XVth Olympic Winter Games - Venues to Match the Events] * [http://www.calgaryspeedskating.ca Calgary Speed Skating Association - CSSA] {{Calgary landmarks}} {{1988 Winter Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues in speed skating}} {{University of Calgary}} [[Category:Venues of the 1988 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:Indoor speed skating venues]] [[Category:Olympic speed skating venues]] [[Category:School buildings completed in 1987]] [[Category:Speed skating venues in Canada]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1987]] [[Category:Sports venues in Calgary]] [[Category:University of Calgary]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization | name = Romanian Tennis Federation
''Federația Română de Tenis'' | image = frt_logo.png | image_border = | size = 150px | caption = | map = | msize = | mcaption = | motto = Valoare prin tenis
''(Value through tennis)'' | formation = 1912 | extinction = | type = | headquarters = Bucharest | location = Romania | membership = | language = | leader_title = President | leader_name = [[George Cosac]] | key_people = | num_staff = | budget = | website = [http://www.frt.ro/ Official] }} The '''Romanian Tennis Federation''' ('''FRT''') ([[Romanian language|Romanian]]: ''Federația Română de Tenis'') is the governing body of [[tennis]] in [[Romania]]. It is based in [[Bucharest]] and its current president is former Romanian tennis player [[George Cosac]].{{cite news | title = George Cosac este noul preşedinte al Federaţiei Române de Tenis! | url = http://doartenis.ro/2013/02/george-cosac-este-noul-presedinte-al-federatiei-romane-de-tenis/#inscore_ifheight_xdc_1583 | work = doartenis.ro | date = 2013-02-22 | accessdate= }} It also organizes the [[Romania Davis Cup team]] and the [[Romania Fed Cup team]]. The federation was formed in 1912 and became a member of the [[International Tennis Federation]] (ITF) in the same year. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.frt.ro/ro/en_home Official Website] * [http://www.cosr.ro/sporturi_de_vara.html?id_sport=23 Romanian Olympic Committee: Tennis Federation] {{National Members of the International Tennis Federation}} {{Sports governing bodies in Romania}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Federatia Romana de Tenis}} [[Category:National members of Tennis Europe|Romania]] [[Category:Tennis in Romania]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Romania|Tennis]] [[Category:1912 establishments in Romania]] {{tennis-stub}} {{Romania-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = Salomon Group | logo = Salomon logo.png | type = [[Subsidiary]]
of [[Amer Sports]] | foundation = 1947, {{Years or months ago|1947}} | founder = Georges Salomon | location_city = [[Épagny-Metz-Tessy]] | location_country = [[France]] | location = | num_employees = 2,800 (2004) | industry = [[Snowsports]], [[Hiking]] | products = | parent = [[Adidas]] (1997–2005)
[[Amer Sports]]
(2005–present) | subsid = [[Mavic]]| | revenue = [[Euro|€]]683 million (2004) | net_income = | homepage = [http://www.salomon.com/ salomon.com] }} The '''Salomon Group''' (also just known as "'''Salomon'''") is a sports equipment manufacturing company that originated in [[Annecy]], [[France]]. The company was started in 1947 by François Salomon, his wife, and son Georges (1925-2010). In 1997, it was acquired by [[Adidas]] in a $1Bn deal.{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xDrY3hPDp48C&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38#v=onepage&q&f=false |magazine=Skiing Heritage |title=Georges Salomon |last=Hogen |first=Jackson |date=December 2010 |page=44 }}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IepPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OwgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6843%2C300242 |newspaper=Ocala Star-Banner |location=Florida |agency=Associated Press |last=Sirak |first=Ron |title=Organizers announce field for Skins Game |date=September 17, 1997 |page=6D }} In 2005, Adidas-Salomon announced on May 2 that it had agreed to sell the Salomon Group for [[Euro|€]]485 million to [[Amer Sports]] of [[Finland]]; the transaction was completed on October 20.[http://www.salomonsports.com/docs/Press-release_02%2005%2005-e.pdf adidas-Salomon agrees to sell Salomon to Amer Sports Corporation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070103131228/http://www.salomonsports.com/docs/Press-release_02%2005%2005-e.pdf |date=2007-01-03 }} from adidas-salomon.com ==Company information== The family's metalworking shop opened in 1947 to produce saw blades. They soon adapted their equipment to make steel edges for skis and progressed to cable bindings.{{cite news |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p1BEAc165jUC&pg=PA100&lpg=PA100#v=onepage&q&f=false |magazine=Skiing |title=Salomon atni-sgock-competition step-in |last=Lipe |first=Gordon |date=November 1968 |page=100 }} [[Ski binding|Bindings]] were the primary focus until 1979, when the rear-entry SX90 [[ski boot]] was introduced; [[ski]]s came a decade later. [[TaylorMade-Adidas|Taylor Made]] golf was acquired by the company in the mid-1980s. Salomon currently does not have a global CEO, as the business is separated between Winter Sports, Footwear and Apparel. Heikki Takala is the CEO of its mother group, Amer Sports, headquartered in Helsinki (Finland). The US operations of Salomon are located in Ogden, Utah. Other companies owned by the Salomon brand include: *[[Bonfire Snowboarding|Bonfire]] *[[Mavic]] ===Market=== [[File:Skis Salomon 01.jpg|thumb|Landmark Salomon skis: the 1080 and the Axecleaver]] Salomon produces products for various sports markets, including [[trail running]], [[hiking]], [[climbing]], [[adventure racing]], [[ski]]ing, and [[snowboard]]ing in over 40 countries on five continents. They used to manufacture [[inline skates]], transferring technologies from their ski boot range, but have not released any in recent years (possibly due to an infringement judgement).[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Judgement+Forces+Salomon+to+Cease+All+Sales+of+Alleged...-a054268448 Judgement Forces Salomon to Cease All Sales of Alleged Patent-Infringing Skates] from thefreelibrary.com Many in-line skaters consider these to be some of the highest quality skates for street and vert skating.{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}} ===Design=== [[File:Salomon Divine RS CF.JPG|thumb|A Salomon alpine boot (2010).]] After a five-year research project, the SX series of ski boots was introduced in the beginning of the 1980s. The boot was the result of collaboration with the French designer [[Roger Tallon]]. The SX91 ski boot was launched in 1984, the result of collaboration with the young French designer [[Roger Pitiot]]. The boot contained a number of innovations such as the sliding forward-flex control. Salomon's dedicated design center is in Annecy, France. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Salomon}} *{{official|http://www.salomon.com/}} *[http://winterbadass.com/articles/story-behind-salomon-skis/ Story Behind Salomon Skis] *[https://www.skiinghistory.org/lives/georges-salomon Skiing History] - Georges P.J. Salomon *[http://patents.justia.com/assignee/ets-francois-salomon-et-fils-s-a Justia] - Salomon patents {{Amer Sports}} {{Running Shoe Brands}} {{Portal|Companies}} [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of France]] [[Category:Outdoor clothing brands]] [[Category:Clothing companies of France]] [[Category:French brands]] [[Category:Sporting goods brands]] [[Category:Ski equipment manufacturers]] [[Category:Adidas]] [[Category:Shoe companies of France]] [[Category:Sport in Annecy]] [[Category:1947 establishments in France]]

{{multiple issues| {{Advert|date=October 2009}} {{Unreferenced|date=October 2009}} }}
'''Snowflex''' is a snow sports surfacing product, invented and manufactured by Briton Engineering Developments Ltd of [[Holmfirth, West Yorkshire]] in the UK.
[[File:Piste de ski de Noeux-les-Mines.JPG|thumb|250px|right|''Stade de glisse'' of [[Noeux-les-Mines]], [[France]] with the Snowflex snowsports system]]
==Definition== Snowflex is an artificial snow surface. The surface system is made of a polymer composite, comprising a monofilament fibre and impregnated carrier layer. This sits on top of a shock absorption layer in an attempt to give an authentic responsive and reactive feel. Other components in Snowflex include an integrated misting system, known as BritonMist, for friction reduction and an impervious membrane for recycling of water. The base is a woven controlling layer which prevents earth movement. The surface layer is manufactured in tile form and as such Snowflex forms a [[wiktionary:Homogenous|homogenous]] system which can be cut and formed into features and shapes such as those found in alpine environments.
==Qualities==
* Slip and grip: Maximum forward speed; extra edge control for turning; realism is lost without speed and edge control * Safety: Ultra cushioning for falls; no holes in surface layer to get caught in; no sharp edges/surface metal to cause abrasions or cuts. * Form-ability: Ability to create adventurous and interesting terrain and stunt formations
Due to the complex nature of Snowflex, it is not possible to self-install. Instead the company which designed and manufactures it operates as installers as well. This is a first for snowsports surfaces as previous materials were able to be installed by slope operators at their own cost.
==Skiing Centers Using Snowflex==
Following its launch in 1996 Snowflex has been installed at over fifty full scale slope operations, including: [[Bearsden]], near Glasgow; Noeux les Mines in northern France (pictured above); [[Valladolid]] in Spain. There are many minor training installations around the world including Olympic training centres in the USA, Switzerland, Lithuania, Estonia, Latvia, Germany, Finland etc.
Many other full scale installations can be seen around the world, including France as mentioned previously, Turkey (where the worlds largest synthetic slope is currently installedin Ankara), South Africa, and the USA. Installations in the United States can be seen at the Liberty Mountain Snowflex Centre near [[Liberty University]] in [[Lynchburg, Virginia]], the YMCA of the Rockies in Colorado and at Wolfe Mountain Snowflex slope in Branson, Missouri.
Liberty Mountain Snowflex Centre in Lynchburg, Virginia, was the first Snowflex facility in the United States to open to the public.<ref>Doble, Mike (2009) [http://www.skisoutheast.com/Liberty-Mountain-Snowflex-Centre-Grand-Opening/ “Liberty Mountain Snowflex Centre Grand Opening”] SkiSoutheast.com</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yzOBnSG6OxU Liberty University's Snowflex Centre] video at YouTube.com</ref> The year round outdoor ski and snowboard slope includes both a beginner slope and an intermediate slope, as well as three big air kickers with a ninety foot long landing ramp, an 11' tall quarter pipe and wall ride. It also has multiple boxes and rail features for all levels of riders. Two carpet lifts take skiers to the top; a surface cable lift also tows skiers upward.
==See also== *[[Artificial ski slopes]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.snowflex.com/ Official Snowflex Web Site] *[http://www.liberty.edu/snowflex Official Liberty Mountain Snowflex Centre Web Site]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{good article}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Sør Arena | nickname = | image = Sør-Arena-1.jpg | location = Torsvika, [[Kristiansand]], [[Norway]] | broke_ground = 11 January 2006 | opened = 15 April 2007 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Kristiansand|Kristiansand Kommune]] | operator = Sørlandshallen Eiendom AS | surface = Artificial grass | construction_cost = [[Norwegian krone|NOK]] 400 million | architect = [[Kjell Kosberg]] | former_names = | tenants = [[IK Start]] (2007–) | seating_capacity = 14,563 | suites = | record_attendance = 14,448 | coordinates = {{Coord|58|9|13|N|8|1|43|E|type:landmark_region:NO|display=inline,title}} }}
'''Sør Arena''' ("South Arena") is a [[football (soccer)|football]] [[stadium]] located at Torsvika in [[Kristiansand]], [[Norway]]. The [[all-seater stadium|all-seater]] has a capacity of 14,563 people, and serves as the home ground of [[Tippeligaen]] side [[IK Start]]. It was designed by [[Kjell Kosberg]], and is architecturally similar to [[Aker Stadion]]. The venue has seen concerts by [[Elton John]], [[Dolly Parton]] and [[A-ha]], among others.. [[UEFA]] refers to the stadium as '''Kristiansand Arena'''.
Construction started in 2006, and the stadium opened on 15 April 2007, replacing [[Kristiansand Stadion]] as Start's home ground. The venue cost 400 million [[Norwegian krone]] (NOK), of which the stadium itself cost NOK 250 million, after significant [[cost overrun]]s. While originally planned with [[artificial turf]], the venue was ultimately built with a natural grass pitch. The venue and the holding company Start Stadion were taken over by Sparebanken Sør, the main [[creditor]], in 2008. They subsequently also took over Start Toppfotball, the company running the club. Both companies were sold to [[Ernst Ravnaas]] in 2009. Following decreased attendance, ahead of the 2011 season the seating on the corners was sold as advertisement space and the maximum capacity has artificially been reduced to 11,700.
==History== [[File:Sor-arena-aerial-view-2006-10-19.jpg|left|thumb|Sør Arena during construction]]
Traditionally, Start has played their home games at Kristiansand Stadion, a municipal [[multi-purpose stadium]]. In May 2005, the municipal council approved the plans for a new stadium for Start. At the time, the structure was estimated to cost NOK 177 million, of which NOK 120 million would be for the stadium itself, while the remaining would be for commercial properties.<ref name=kjempegjeld>{{cite web |url=http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2008/04/11/532222.html |title=Ny stadion har gitt Start kjempegjeld |work=[[Dagbladet]] |date=11 April 2008 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2uhg49X?url=http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2008/04/11/532222.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=space>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/sport_nrk_sorlandet/1.3618042 |title=Sør Arena tre ganger dyrere |last=Pedersen |first=Kjell |last2=Rasch |first2=Lars Helge |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=30 September 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2vpjTjW?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/sport_nrk_sorlandet/1.3618042 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The club held an [[architecture competition]], and received six bids. On 28 September 2005, Start Toppfotball announced that they had selected the design by Kjell Kosberg from Kosbergs Arkitektkontor, who had previously designed [[Aker Stadion]] and [[Briskeby Arena]]. The default proposal contained a spectator capacity for 9,948 people, but the plans were scalable, allowing for increased capacity if the club so wanted. Ernst Ravnaas, co-owner of the club, stated that given the recent high attendance, he wanted to build a larger stadium than the default proposal. Financing was planned with a free lot from [[Kristiansand Municipality]], a NOK 40 million loan from the municipality, a NOK 20 million grant from [[Cultiva]], a municipal culture fund, NOK 20 in [[value added tax]] refund, NOK 10 to 20 million in [[naming rights]], the sale of commercial property, NOK 30 to 40 million in a bank loan, and the remaining with share capital from Start Toppfotball.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/article310949.ece |title=Slik blir Starts stadion i Marvika |last=Enersen |first=Svein |last2=Sandvik |first2=Arild |last3=Svardal |first3=Asgeir |last4=Svela |first4=Elling |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=28 September 2005 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1JAm3q8?url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/article310949.ece |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:SoerArena.JPG|thumb|During construction]] In October, the club stated that they hoped to finance a further expansion of the stadium to 14,000 seats by selling part of the lot to a private developer, which would use it to build a 17-story building.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/article315151.ece?redir=true |title=Stadion - slik Start ønsker |last=Sandvik |first=Arild |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=17 October 2005 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1S5gboA?url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/article315151.ece?redir=true |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 23 December, Rasmussengruppen signed a contract where they bought shares worth NOK 45 million in Start Toppfotball. In addition, they paid NOK 15 million for the right to build {{convert|11000|m2|sp=us}} of commercial property in conjunction with the stadium, and an [[option contract|option]] to purchase the high-rise lot for NOK 25 million. The high-rise lot was again bought from the municipality for NOK 15 million. Combined with the free lot for the stadium, Start Toppfotball received municipal [[subsidies]] of NOK 25 million for constructing the venue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/nyheter/article448553.ece?redir=true |title=Budt 30 mill. - selger for 25 |last=Reinertsen |first=Rune Øidne |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=28 February 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1S5gboA?url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/article315151.ece?redir=true |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
A controversy arose regarding whether to lay natural or artificial turf. [[Kristofer Hæstad]], one of Start's star players, stated that he would not continue to play for the club if artificial turf was laid.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2006/01/20/455318.html |title=Doffen vil stikke fra Start |last=Andresen |first=Gorm |work=[[Dagbladet]] |date=20 January 2006 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1S5gboA?url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/article315151.ece?redir=true |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The contract with the municipality stated that the stadium would have to be built with [[artificial turf]]. In March, Start decided that they would instead lay natural grass, and if necessary pay the municipality for the cost of building another artificial turf venue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/nyheter/article448553.ece?redir=true |title=Budt 30 mill. - selger for 25 |last=Reinertsen |first=Rune Øidne |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=28 February 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1S5gboA?url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/article315151.ece?redir=true |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The name of the venue was announced on 21 October, after the club had signed a ten-year naming rights agreement with Sparebanken Sør worth NOK 35 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ba.no/sport/fotball/brann/article2485181.ece?service=print |title=Vil ikke selge Brann-sjelen |last=Pamer |first=Anders |work=[[Bergensavisen]] |date=22 December 2006 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1WkBYn5?url=http://www.ba.no/sport/fotball/brann/article2485181.ece?service=print |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2006/10/21/480462.html |title=Starts nye stadion skal hete Sør Arena |last=Strand |first=Sigbjørn |work=[[Dagbladet]] |date=21 October 2006 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1WvcSlh?url=http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2006/10/21/480462.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The rights to sell the naming rights were first transferred from the stadium owner to the company Rettighetskompaniet AS, which subsequently sold these to Sparebanken Sør.<ref name=bankrupt>{{cite web |url=http://www.nettavisen.no/sport/fotball/article3627650.ece |title=Start Stadion AS begjærer oppbud |agency=[[Norwegian News Agency]] |work=[[Nettavisen]] |date=23 May 2013 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 November 2013 |archivedate=17 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LCnIddSR?url=http://www.nettavisen.no/sport/fotball/article3627650.ece |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:Sør Arena 060720085937.jpg|thumb|left|The pitch]] Construction of the stadium was subject to significant cost overruns. These were mostly caused by the increased size of both spectator and commercial area, increased standard to VIP facilities, a general increase in construction costs, and the deadline to finish the venue in time for the league to start. Total investments exceeded NOK 400 million, of which 250 million was paid for by Start. This resulted in the stadium company having a debt of NOK 173 million, in addition to NOK 60 million in share equity.<ref name=kjempegjeld /><ref name=space /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.3246327 |title=Må låne mer penger |last=Jakobsen |first=Marianne |last2=Nilsen |first2=Anne Torhild |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=20 August 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2u3hKRd?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.3970684 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In November 2007, Start sold {{convert|2500|m2|sp=us}} of commercial space at the stadium for NOK 25 million to finance part of the cost overrun.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.3970684 |title=Selger deler av Sør Arena |last=Pedersen |first=Kjell |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=7 November 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2u3hKRd?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.3970684 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The opening of the stadium took place on 15 April 2007, in the season's first league game, against [[Viking FK|Viking]]. The game attracted 14,448 spectators, a record attendance and the only time the venue has been sold out.<ref name=svikter>{{cite web |url=http://fotball.fvn.no/eliteserien/article83338.ece |title=Svikter Sør Arena |last=Brenne |first=Øyvind |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=13 June 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/article464399.ece |title=Sør Arena er offisielt åpnet |last=Arnli |first=Ann Magritt |last2=Flaa |first2=Jørund |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=15 April 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1S5gboA?url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/article315151.ece?redir=true |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> After the opening, the pitch was the worst in the league, and by May the grass within the [[penalty area]]s and along the one side had been replaced.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2007/05/10/500292.html |title=Været kan gjøre Start-matta enda dårligere |last=Haraldsen |first=Stian |work=[[Dagbladet]] |date=10 May 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1WvcSlh?url=http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2006/10/21/480462.html |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> By 2010, the pitch quality had improved and was regarded as "world class" by the Start players.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fotball.fvn.no/eliteserien/article171307.ece |title=Mener Sør Arena holder verdensklasse |last=Jørgensen |first=Pål |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=6 June 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref> The cost of preparing the pitch, including snow removal, ahead of the season is about NOK 500,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.7033103 |title=Svindyrt gress |last=Raustøl |first=Håvard |last2=Nilsen |first2=Anne Torhild |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=11 March 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2LWOlqn?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.7033103 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Ahead of the 2008 season, the 1,400 [[club seating|club seats]] had to be replaced for a cost of NOK 1.5 million, because the wood in the chairs were rotting. The reason was that the chairs were designed for in-door use, and the necessary precautions to protect them when not in use had not been taken.<ref name=clubseating>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.6578693 |title=Start i million-krangel |last=Refset |first=Aud |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=23 April 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2tuaFm2?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.6578693 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The stadium had a book value of NOK 230 million, way over the real value, causing Start Toppfotball to have to write down the investment. To finance this, Sparebanken Sør, the main creditor, bought Start Stadion from Start Toppfotball for NOK 2,600 on 23 December 2008.<ref name=arvesolvet>{{cite web |url=http://fotball.fvn.no/eliteserien/article131446.ece |title=Start solgte arvesølvet |last=Jørgensen |first=Pål |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=7 March 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref> At the same time, the club signed a 40-year agreement to [[lease]] the stadium from Sparebanken Sør for NOK 12 million per year.<ref name=arvesolvet /><ref name=takkernei>{{cite web |url=http://fotball.fvn.no/eliteserien/article140525.ece |title=Takker nei til kjøp av Sør Arena |last=Uleberg |first=Odd I. R. |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=29 May 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref> On 7 March 2009, the bank also bought the remaining shares of Start Toppfotball, becoming the sole owner of both the club and the stadium.<ref name=arvesolvet /> Sparebanken Sør offered to sell Sparebanken Sør Arena to the municipality for NOK 100 million, but the municipality rejected this on 29 May.<ref name=takkernei /> The bank subsequently sold Start Stadion and Start Toppfotball to Ravnaas on 25 June for NOK 1 each.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.6811636 |title=Kjøpte Start for 2 kroner |last=Nilsen |first=Anne Torild |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=9 October 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=8 July 2011 |archivedate=8 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6024GjBfC?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.6811636 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Start Stadion had at the time a debt of NOK 34 million to Start Toppfotball, NOK 60 million to Sparebanken Sør and NOK 40 million to Kristiansand Municipality. Sparebanken Sør lost NOK 80 million in their transactions with Start and Sparebanken Sør Arena.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dn.no/forsiden/naringsliv/article1694770.ece |title=Ernst Ravnaas overtar Start |last=Berglihn |first=Harald |work=[[Dagens Næringsliv]] |date=25 June 2009 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1E2Wouu?url=http://www.dn.no/forsiden/naringsliv/article1694770.ece |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:IK Start 08.jpg|thumb|Inside view]]
Following a fall in game attendance in [[2009 Norwegian Premier League|2009]] and [[2010 Norwegian Premier League|2010]], Start decided ahead of the [[2011 Norwegian Premier League|2011 season]] to reduce the stadium's capacity. Advertisement banners were sold to cover the corners, thus reducing the capacity to 11,700 tickets. The club stated that the intention was to move spectators closer together to increase the atmosphere, and at the same time making it easier to sell out the stadium.<ref name=reduserer>{{cite web |url=http://fotball.fvn.no/eliteserien/article184136.ece |title=Start reduserer publikumskapasiteten |last=Karlsen |first=Håvard |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=28 October 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref> In February 2012, [[Kristiansand District Court]] sentenced Start to pay NOK 6.4 million in value added tax on the naming rights. The club stated that they believed the naming rights were exempt.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.7997401 |title=Start må betale 6.4 millioner etter nederlag i retten |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |last=Larsen |first=Lars Erik |date=15 February 2012 |accessdate=15 February 2012 |archivedate=15 February 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65TSqsBzx?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.7997401 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> After the [[2011 Norwegian Premier League|2011 season]], Start was again relegated to the First Division. In an attempt to better the club's financial situation, Start agreed to lay artificial turf on Sparebanken Sør Arena, in exchange for NOK 250,000 in municipal funding to use the stadium for recreational sports.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2012/02/13/sport/fotball/start/sor_arena/20220617/ |title=Sør Arena blir kunstgressbane |work=[[Dagbladet]] |date=13 February 2012 |accessdate=29 May 2012 |archivedate=29 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/681by9af4?url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2012/02/13/sport/fotball/start/sor_arena/20220617/ |language=Norwegian |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Removal of the natural pitch started on 28 May 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://fotball.aftenposten.no/forstediv/article238372.ece<!--|title=Her fjernes Norges fineste gressmatte-->|title=Sør Arena blir kunstgressbane |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=28 May 2012 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=29 May 2012}}</ref>
Start won the [[2012 Norwegian First Division]] and were promoted to the top league for their [[2013 IK Start season|2013 season]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2012/10/21/sport/fotball/tippeligaen/adeccoligaen/start/23975370/ |title=Start tilbake til Tippeligaen |work=[[Dagbladet]] |date=21 October 2012 |accessdate=17 November 2013 |archivedate=17 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LCpnlIsp?url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2012/10/21/sport/fotball/tippeligaen/adeccoligaen/start/23975370/ |language=Norwegian |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Start Stadion had been involved in a legal suit with the [[Norwegian Tax Administration]] over whether [[value added tax]] was to be paid for the stadium's naming rights. The company lost the case both in [[Agder Court of Appeal]] and the [[Supreme Court of Norway|Supreme Court]], resulting in the company having to pay NOK 9 million in taxes. As the company did not have such values, it was forced to filed for bankruptcy on 23 May 2013. At the time the company had a debt of NOK 107 million.<ref name=bankrupt /> At the time the municipality has commenced negotiations with Sparebanken Sør to purchase the stadium.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fvn.no/100Sport/fotball/eliteserien/-143007_1.snd<!--|title=Her fjernes Norges fineste gressmatte-->|title=Kommunen vurderer å kjøpe Sparebanken Sør Arena |last=Lindblom |first=Frode |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=21 May 2013 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref> Football economist Tor Geir Kvinen stated that Sparebanken Sør had by then spent NOK 200 million on subsidizing Start and that in reality the municipality and bank were funding the repeated deficits in the club.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vg.no/sport/fotball/norsk/artikkel.php?artid=10135683 |title=Ekspert: – Start driver tragisk økonomistyring |work=[[Verdens Gang]] |date=7 October 2013 |accessdate=17 November 2013 |archivedate=17 November 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LCorQO7r?url=http://www.vg.no/sport/fotball/norsk/artikkel.php?artid=10135683 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The municipality announced a plan in October 2013, whereby they would purchase the bank's NOK 54 million loan for NOK 44 million and receive all the shares in the stadium company. The bank would then buy the naming rights for ten more years for NOK 10 million and yet unsold commercial property. The municipality would then be owed NOK 64 million by the stadium company, up from NOK 46 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aftenposten.no/100Sport/fotball/eliteserien/Skal-hete-Sor-Arena-i-20-ar-397222_1.snd<!--|title=Her fjernes Norges fineste gressmatte-->|title=Skal hete Sør Arena i 20 år |last=Jørgensen |first=Pål |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=10 October 2013 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref>
==Facilities== [[File:Kristiansand Stadium 01.jpg|thumb|Main facade]] The stadium has a capacity for 14,563 spectators,<ref name=svikter /> of which 1,400 are [[club seating]].<ref name=clubseating /> However, the seating is artificially reduced to 11,700.<ref name=reduserer /> Built into the stadium is {{convert|22000|m2|sp=us}} of commercial property.<ref name=space /> The venue has many architectural similarities with [[Aker Stadion]], home of [[Molde FK]], which was also designed by Kosberg.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fotball.fvn.no/eliteserien/article78770.ece |title=Paulsen kaller Sør Arena fantastisk |last=Brenne |first=Øyvind |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=11 April 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref> During one winter, the pitch was accidentally converted to a [[bandy]] field, when it was covered with a layer of ice up to {{convert|10|cm|sp=us|0}} thick because of cold weather.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.7531012 |title=Skøytebane på Sør Arena |last=Sellevold |first=Terje |work=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=2 March 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=17 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1Jqi4t1?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/sorlandet/1.7531012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Events== The [[Norway national under-21 football team]] won 2–0 over [[Estonia national under-21 football team|Estonia]] at Sparebanken Sør Arena on 20 November 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fotball.no/System-pages/TabellTermin/?tournamentId=39901 |title=Norge Menn U21 |publisher=[[Football Association of Norway]] |language=Norwegian |archivedate=26 November 2011 |accessdate=26 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63UG3Ayfy?url=http://www.fotball.no/System-pages/TabellTermin/?tournamentId=39901 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The stadium hosted a [[UEFA Women's Euro 2009 qualifying]] match on 3 May 2008, in which [[Norway women's national football team|Norway]] beat [[Israel women's national football team|Israel]] 7–0.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/womenseuro/season=2009/matches/round=2381/match=85494/postmatch/report/index.html |title=Norway maintain perfect record |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=3 May 2008 |accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref> The final in the [[2011–13 International Challenge Trophy]] was held at the stadium on 14 August 2013, in which the [[Norway national under-23 football team]] lost 0–1 in extra time against [[Turkey A2 national football team|Turkey A2]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tff.org/default.aspx?pageID=471&ftxtID=18701 |title=A2 National Team win Int'l Challenge Trophy |publisher=[[Turkish Football Federation]] |accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref>
Concerts held at the stadium have included [[Elton John]] in 2007, which attracted a crowd of 19,000,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/kultur/musikk/article489434.ece |title=En lykkekveld på Sør Arena |last=Syvertsen |first=Emil Otto |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=26 June 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y2HOWRUQ?url=http://www.fvn.no/kultur/musikk/article489434.ece |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Dolly Parton]] in 2008<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/kultur/musikk/article534576.ece?redir=true |title=Sir Elton John spiller på Sør Arena |last=Eikeland |first=Torgeir |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=27 November 2007 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1XdX688?url=http://www.fvn.no/kultur/musikk/article534576.ece?redir=true |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and [[A-ha]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/kultur/musikk/musikkanmeldelser/article792020.ece |title=Sir Elton John spiller på Sør Arena |last=Eikeland |first=Torgeir |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=12 September 2010 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1XkXSyR?url=http://www.fvn.no/kultur/musikk/musikkanmeldelser/article792020.ece |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A 2008 tour with artists from [[Norske Talenter]] and [[Idol (Norway)|Idol]] attracted only 800 people, including free entrants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/kultur/article598238.ece?redir=true |title=Idol-flopp på Sør-Arena |last=Mikaelsen |first=Ingrid |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=13 July 2008 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1bH4ABl?url=http://www.fvn.no/kultur/article598238.ece?redir=true |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> From 2011, the finals in PlussbankCup, a junior football tournament held in Kristiansand, are hosted at Sparebanken Sør Arena.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fvn.no/sport/lokal_fotball/article828302.ece |title=Får innpass på Sør Arena |last=Samuelsen |first=Kjetil |work=[[Fædrelandsvennen]] |date=26 January 2011 |language=Norwegian |accessdate=17 April 2011 |archivedate=18 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y1XkXSyR?url=http://www.fvn.no/kultur/musikk/musikkanmeldelser/article792020.ece |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
